subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Schumpeter's Gale: The Storm That Builds Economies
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Schumpeter's Gale: The Storm That Builds Economies.

hook.text: In 1942, economist Joseph Schumpeter coined a terrifying phrase: 'creative destruction.' It changed economics.

buildup.text: Schumpeter argued that capitalism doesn't grow by standing still. It grows by destroying what came before.

discovery.text: The steam engine killed canal transport. The car killed the horse industry. The computer killed the typewriter.

twist.text: Each wave of destruction didn't shrink the economyâ€”it expanded it. The new industries were always bigger.

climax.text: Schumpeter showed that economic progress requires letting old industries die so new ones can be born.

punchline.text: Capitalism's greatest engine is also its wrecking ball.

quiz.question: What did Joseph Schumpeter mean by 'creative destruction'?
options: That innovation requires government intervention to tear down monopolies
That economic progress requires old industries to die so new ones can emerge
That entrepreneurs must destroy their competitors to succeed
